awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: GOALI: A Membrane Contactor Based Reactive Separation Process for Fuel Alcohol Production for Distributed-Type Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The conversion of distributed biomass resources from agricultural waste into liquid transportation fuels can have significant potential economic benefits to rural communities and also can improve global environmental sustainability. The proposed project aims to develop a novel process for converting waste biomass to alcohol fuels that is suitable for small-scale operations, employs fewer processing steps than existing methods, and produces higher yields with improved energy efficiency and inherent safety. The team of researchers collaborates with an industrial partner, Sheeta Global Technology Co., to develop and test the proposed biomass to alcohol conversion technology. 

This research project focuses on the development of a novel membrane contactor reactor that integrates methanol synthesis with in situ separation of the product using an inorganic membrane and an ionic liquid stream. The main research objective is to develop a simple, safer, high-yield alcohol synthesis process that utilizes biomass as a feedstock and has the advantage of using fewer processing steps than existing methods, minimizing product separation requirements, needing less expensive reactors, managing heat more effectively, and requiring less expensive feed gas.  The design of the membrane contactor reactor prevents direct contact of the ionic liquid with the catalyst by separating the two components with an inorganic membrane. The membrane is designed to allow only the product methanol to pass through while preventing passage other gaseous compounds.  Therefore, any potential loss of the ionic liquid through reaction with the catalyst is minimized, and the liquid stream that carries the product is not contaminated with catalytic particle fines. Successful completion of the project may lead to pilot-plant scale testing in collaboration with the industrial partner. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students in research, there is a plan to engage undergraduate students in the development of hands-on teaching modules that will be used for outreach to middle schools.  These outreach activities would serve students from underrepresented and disadvantaged groups in collaboration with USC's Mathematics, Engineering, Science Achievement (MESA) program.

por.por_cntn:
Our project’s goal was to develop a robust novel process to produce a transportation biofuel (methanol) from biomass which is appropriate to use in smaller-scale biomass utilization projects. Developing such a process would make it possible for a large quantity of rural and/or waste biomass to be utilized, which would otherwise be burned directly to generate significant amounts of CO2, a powerful greenhouse gas (GHG), and would help to reduce our Nation’s GHG emissions and our dependence on foreign oil.

            During our study, we investigated a novel process, which integrates MeOH synthesis (MeS) with its in-situ separation through a membrane-assisted contactor reactor (MCR) system employing a low volatility, high alcohol solubility solvent. Potential advantages of such a high-yield alcohol synthesis process for the utilization of biomass as feedstock include: (1) Fewer processing steps; (2) minimized separation requirements; (3) less expensive reactors; (4) more effective heat management; (5) cheaper feed gas requirements (no O2 separation needed); and (6) simple, proven process design and inherent safety. 

            In our research we used the basic, but sound, and effective MCR technical concept together with “off-the-self” membranes and existing commercial alcohol solvents (e.g., ionic liquids (IL) and high boiling point petroleum liquids) to implement the proposed novel MeOH synthesis process. Some key outcomes of our research effort include the following: (1) We generated the solid scientific basis needed for implementing the MCR concept to facilitate bio-syngas conversion into MeOH with a target to achieve a single-pass CO yield > 85%; (2) we demonstrated the MCR concept’s technical feasibility at the lab-scale; and (3) we provided detailed laboratory data of improvements in energy use, environmental performance, product yield and selectivity, and economic benefits for biomass utilization.

            This is a NSF GOALI project involving the integral participation of a small US Business (SGTC). For our industrial partners, the project provided access to newly developed fundamental tools of discovery. For the students involved (seven graduate and four undergraduate), this research project offered a valuable educational experience and training, providing them with the opportunity to prepare and characterize novel new materials, and to learn 'state-of-the-art' research techniques. It also allowed them to interact with industrial researchers.

            The successful completion of this joint industrial/academic study allowed us to gain the solid scientific foundation and fundamental understanding needed in order to be able to develop and optimize the proposed solvent-mediated MCR system for biomass utilization. Jointly with our industrial partner SGTC, we are presently exploring the possibility of additional development efforts at the pilot plant scale level, with the hope that successful completion of such studies will lead into the eventual commercialization of the process.  Our preliminary estimates indicate that in comparison with the conventional processes (e.g., the Lurgi MeOH process), our proposed single-pass, high-conversion syngas-to-MeOH process offers potential energy savings of ~15%. Note furthermore, that due to its complexity the gigantic-size Lurgi process is not appropriate for biomass applications.
